name: Tioga Road
description: Widely considered the most famous scenic drive in Yosemite, this 46-mile route travels from Crane Flat to Tioga Pass, showcasing the park's high country scenery.
best_time: Late May or early June through November
tips: Typically closed from late May/June until November
Check current road conditions before heading out
Closed for the season due to snow in winter months

name: Yosemite Valley Loop
description: The most popular of all Yosemite drives, this loop showcases awesome landscapes and breathtaking vistas that make the park famous. Although often crowded, it provides a must-see introduction to the valley's iconic scenery.
tips: Expect heavy crowds as it is the most popular route
Be aware of vehicle restrictions

name: Glacier Point Road
description: A stunning drive that leads to the Glacier Point overlook, offering panoramic views of Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls.
tips: Closed beyond Badger Pass for the season due to snow
Be prepared for tire chain requirements during winter months
Check status of road closures before travel

name: Wawona Road
description: This road connects Yosemite Valley to the southern part of the park, providing access to the historic Wawona area and the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias.
tips: Snow is possible on this road
Tire chain requirements may be in effect during winter

name: Highway 41 (Wawona Road)
description: A route heading north into the park that travels mostly through dense forest. While primarily tree-lined, the drive features several creek crossings and culminates in the famous Tunnel View overlook.
tips: Roll down your windows to enjoy the scent of the trees and bearclover.
Be prepared for mostly forest views until you exit the Wawona Tunnel.
Numerous turn-outs between Wawona and Chinquapin offer opportunities for solitude.

name: Hetch Hetchy Road
description: A drive leading to the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in the northwestern section of the park, known for its rugged beauty and quieter atmosphere.
tips: Check for specific entrance gate hours as they can vary seasonally

name: Yosemite Valley Roads
description: A series of roads within the valley floor containing a high concentration of iconic natural beauty and famous landmarks.
tips: Many roads in the Valley are one-way; consult a map to understand the traffic flow.
The Yosemite Road Guide is recommended for identifying roadside markers and points of interest.

name: Big Oak Flat Road
description: This route serves as one of the main entrances to the park, climbing from the Yosemite Valley floor toward the Big Oak Flat Entrance.
tips: Access point for the Tioga Road at Crane Flat

name: El Portal Road
description: Running between Yosemite Valley and El Portal, this drive offers marvelous sights, particularly through the Merced River Canyon.
tips: Look for wildflowers in the spring
Commonly used for access to rafting and hiking

name: Sierra Vista Byway
description: Travels through beautiful meadows and forests, past towering peaks and huge granite outcroppings with unique historical stops.
tips: Stop at Mile High Vista for broad landscape views

name: Highway 108
description: A route from Sonora to Bridgeport that offers breathtaking scenery including volcanic geological features and mountain passes.
tips: Drive over the scenic Sonora Pass
Visit the Columns of the Giants in Stanislaus National Forest

name: Highway 49
description: A long, historic route following the path of the Gold Rush 49ers, passing through numerous historic mining towns and sites.
tips: Great for history buffs interested in the Gold Rush era
